content.description: Perfect Woodson slab/face.  Don't even think about it if it's hot.
content.location: Located on the South face of the largest boulder South of the Painted boulder.

content.description: A striking arete with overhanging start.

climbs.name: Stealth Bomber
climbs.fa: Lance Hughson and Dan Leichtfuss, May 1988

content.description: Thin smears up and right to the arete
content.location: Around right on same boulder as Eric's crack

content.description:
A nice off-width boulder problem in the playground area.

After multiple laps on right-side-in off-width climbs like Maria's, the crucible, big grunt and arch crack, friends and I started joking that left-side-in cracks could only be found south of the equator. Sure there's sickle crack or Eric's crack, but when I found this one, it just felt natural to call it "South of Ecuador."

Let me be frank... I don't know who climbed this first but I can say with complete certainty it wasn't me. I'm also probably not the first to name it. If you climbed it and have a better name with a better back story, share it! otherwise, get out there and enjoy this little bit off-width awesomeness!
content.protection: Ankle protection, pants and long-sleeves if you're new to off-width.
content.location: South-East of the painted boulder in the playground area.

content.description:
A couple of great boulder problems in a small corridor. The Kennedy/Hubbard guide lists 3 variations, though I could only come up with two.

Rough Boys (Right):

Start on small crimps in the middle of the face and make a big move to the lip/dike feature.

Rough Boys (Left):

Same start in the middle of the face, but traverse left, heading towards a few good knobs to topout on.
Some techy lie backing on a nice blocky feature will get you on better feet where you  an finally reach the top. Looks like there may be potential for a lower start.
content.protection: ~2pads, not tall but landing is uneven
content.location:
When you get to the main switch back that is "The Playground Area" turn left (east) and head on some trails that will take you by "Full Circle" (

mountainproject.com/route/1…

), continue due east and skirt counter clockwise around a large rock. If you skirted around the correct rock it should have a big wedge chunk missing (This might be Long's Mantle). From here get on top of the rock directly opposite the missing wedge. There is a rock leaning on the rock you are standing on which has a cool cave and Glass Animals is on the right side. See beta picture for location.

GPS: (33.005001, -116.965242)

Located about half way between The Control Tower and Full Circle

content.description: The Vomitorium is a perfect atrium on the uphill side of the tunnel near the base of marshmallow tower. Death Vomit is directly over the uphill tunnel exit. Powerful mantle or face pull.
content.location: In the vomitorium.  Head uphill from tower 2 past the marshmallow tower and go through a short tunnel to get there

content.description: The northeast arete of control tower is a bit easier than the north face, climbing rounded holds on the arete to the top
The hard part is a deadpoint pull off the deck. Once established on the face it turns into a 5.6 romp to the top. People use a cheat stone to bypass the 5.11 move. to set the tr rope.
Steep edging off of a nice clean rock shelf. Hardest moves are at the bottom.
content.location: From painted boulder head east and bear right of the huge boulder that "5.10a on the outside" is located on. Continue directly toward the marshmallow tower. The control tower is about 75 feet east of the 5.10a on the outside boulder

content.description: On the backside of the Fallen Gypsy, an obvious traverse capped by a big roof block is seen.
This is a very hard thin lieback/friction route in a shallow dihedral of sorts.
content.protection: TR with a couple of hand sized cams
content.location: From the Painted Boulders, take a very worn trail towards the biggest formation due south.  The boulder has a large cap boulder on it.

content.description: This is the wide crack encountered on the same face as Fallen Gypsy but to its right.

This is the crack climb on the backside of the Fallen Gypsy boulder, same side as Cameron's Traverse.  Cheat stones for the start lead to a bit of an alcove/recess, then up an ever narrowing section of crack to finish.  Super rock quality, but the recess area deters a bit.
